docs.title: Stream (WIP)
docs.text:
Stream is a tiny stream-centric language where programs are pipelines and behavior is described as flow.

The interpreter is sti. A Stream program is a text file (commonly *.program) that defines: - optional metadata (season, drift) - gyge bindings (imports / builtins) - a single entrypoint called spring

docs.title: Hello, world
docs.text:
<-> Hello, Stream!

gyge stdout -:> <o>::fd::stdout;

season -:> spring;
drift -:> gentle;

spring -:> {
  "Hello, world!" -> stdout
}

docs.title: Comments
docs.text:
• <-> starts a comment line:
  • <-> This is a comment

docs.title: Imports / bindings (gyge)
docs.text:
A gyge is a named node/operator you can use in the program. You bind a gyge name to an imported symbol: 

gyge stdout -:> <o>::fd::stdout;
Where stdout is the gyge name used in your pipeline. - <o> is a module meaning “this process” (a safe, process-scoped OS surface)

  • :: traverses namespaces inside that module.: <o>::fd::stdout resolves to a callable sink that prints to standard output

docs.title: Season and drift
docs.text:
These are program-level modifiers: 

season -:> spring;
drift  -:> gentle;
They are currently metadata (and/or runtime policy knobs), and are intended to influence scheduling/behavior as the language grows.

docs.title: Running
docs.text:
From the project root: 

uv run python -m sti path/to/hello.program
Or, if you expose a CLI entrypoint (recommended): 
uv run sti path/to/hello.st

docs.title: Current status
docs.text:
This project is intentionally small and evolving:

The syntax is stabilized around gyge, season/drift, spring, and ->.

The import model uses <module>::path::symbol.

More stream operators (=>, ~>, filters, pack/unpack, errors/signals) will arrive as the interpreter grows.
